Using this DoView model

This is a web page version of a model created by DoView* software (version 5.0). The original DoView file, a PDF of the model, or both, may be available for download from the options bar at the bottom of the screen. To open and edit the original DoView file offline on your local computer, you will need to have installed DoView software, available here.

Navigating a DoView web model

Internal navigation

A model can have many pages. The contents bar on the right hand side of the screen contains all the pages within the model. Display a page by clicking on its name, or by using the green navigation arrows above the contents bar. Some boxes in the model may contain clickable hyperlinks to other parts of the model, which look like (these are called "page-jumps" in DoView).

External web links

Some models may contain clickable links to the web or links to files on the local computer, shown by the icon.

Original DoView file may contain more information than this web page model

This web page model may omit information found in the original DoView file from which it was created. e.g. any off-page notes are not included.

Link icons:  ^  ||

DoView software records any links between boxes, e.g. to show cause and effect (‘this makes happen’ and ‘this is the result of’). It can show links without using lines: the focused box’s border is shown in bold, and those boxes causing it have double vertical lines, ||, on top, and those boxes resulting from it have a rising arrow head on their bottom, ^.

How are DoView web page models created?

DoView web page models are created by DoView software, available here. Create one from within DoView by selecting the File » Create Web Page Model menu option. The web page model will be saved in your preferred subdirectory, ready to be uploaded to a web server (click here for more information).



Footnotes

* DoView© is designed for building simple outcomes models for strategic planning, performance management, evaluation and other purposes. Other names for outcomes models are: strategy models, logic models, means-ends diagrams, program logics, intervention logics, results-chains, program theories, theories of change and strategy maps.
